articles.headline: Only 106,000 Pick Health Insurance Plans in First Month
articles.snippet: New data also show that in the first month of open enrollment, 26,794 signed up through the problem-plagued federal exchange, HealthCare.gov, and the rest through state exchanges.
articles.abstract: New data also show that in the first month of open enrollment, 26,794 signed up through the problem-plagued federal exchange, HealthCare.gov, and the rest through state exchanges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just over 106,000 people picked health plans in the first month of open enrollment through the state and federal insurance marketplaces established by the Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s health secretary said Wednesday, a fraction of the administration’s initial estimate for enrollment during that period.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Good Eggs, a Virtual Farmer’s Market, Delivers Real Food
articles.snippet: The website and delivery service lets you order products online from local farmers and artisanal food producers.
articles.abstract: The website and delivery service lets you order products online from local farmers and artisanal food producers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, my father was fond of ordering steaks through the mail. When they arrived, my sister and I gleefully danced around the icy packages and argued over who got to open them. I can still remember marveling at the novelty of meat arriving in the same pile as regular letters, and our amazement that it tasted as good as — if not better than — the beef we purchased in the supermarket.

articles.headline: With Enrollment Slow, Some Democrats Back Change in Health Law
articles.snippet: Congressional Democrats are increasingly expressing support for allowing Americans to retain the insurance coverage they are losing because of the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: Congressional Democrats are increasingly expressing support for allowing Americans to retain the insurance coverage they are losing because of the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anxious congressional Democrats are threatening to abandon President Obama on a central element of his signature health care law, voicing increasing support for proposals that would allow Americans who are losing their health insurance coverage because of the Affordable Care Act to retain it.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Yellen to Back Stimulus Plan in Remarks to Senators
articles.snippet: The job market and the economy are “performing far short of their potential,” Janet Yellen says in remarks prepared for her Senate confirmation hearing.
articles.abstract: The job market and the economy are “performing far short of their potential,” Janet Yellen says in remarks prepared for her Senate confirmation hearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, President Obama’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve for the next four years, plans to tell senators at her confirmation hearing on Thursday that continuing the Fed’s enormous stimulus campaign is the best way to revive the economy and hasten the program’s end.

articles.headline: At a Philippine Hospital, Survivors Face Quiet Despair
articles.snippet: The main hospital in Tacloban, the Philippine city that bore the brunt of Typhoon Haiyan, lacks the supplies to help the wounded, with some just left to die.
articles.abstract: The main hospital in Tacloban, the Philippine city that bore the brunt of Typhoon Haiyan, lacks the supplies to help the wounded, with some just left to die.
articles.lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Richard Pulga, a 27-year-old farmer with thick black hair and a gentle manner, has been lying on a hard steel bed in a dark hallway of the main hospital here since Saturday with a shattered lower right leg, abdominal pain and his right eye filling with blood.

articles.headline: Rejecting Billions, Snapchat Expects a Better Offer
articles.snippet: Snapchat, a social media service, has become one of the most sought-after businesses in the technology industry.
articles.abstract: Snapchat, a social media service, has become one of the most sought-after businesses in the technology industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: What business makes no money, has yet to pass its third anniversary and just turned down an offer worth billions of dollars? Snapchat, a social media service run by a pair of 20-somethings who until last month worked out of a beachfront bungalow in Venice, Calif.

articles.headline: JPMorgan’s Fruitful Ties to a Member of China’s Elite
articles.snippet: A contract shows that JPMorgan Chase’s relationship with the daughter of China’s former prime minister points to its strategy for building influence in China.
articles.abstract: A contract shows that JPMorgan Chase’s relationship with the daughter of China’s former prime minister points to its strategy for building influence in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: To promote its standing in China, JPMorgan Chase turned to a seemingly obscure consulting firm run by a 32-year-old executive named Lily Chang.
articles.byline: By DAVID BARBOZA, JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and BEN PROTESS

articles.headline: Lawyer Concedes Mistakes in Chevron Case
articles.snippet: In testimony prepared for delivery in court next week, Steven Donziger is as defiant as ever, even as he acknowledges mistakes.
articles.abstract: In testimony prepared for delivery in court next week, Steven Donziger is as defiant as ever, even as he acknowledges mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last month, Chevron has presented a parade of witnesses against Steven R. Donziger, the freelance lawyer who has been suing the company for 20 years over pollution of the Ecuadorean Amazon jungle. One after another, the witnesses, including some of his closest allies and financiers who are now estranged from his cause, have testified that Mr. Donziger committed witness tampering and fraud.

articles.headline: Shopping, Before the Turkey Gets Cold
articles.snippet: The race for consumers’ dollars has prodded more retailers to open their doors on Thanksgiving, a day before the traditional start of the holiday season.
articles.abstract: The race for consumers’ dollars has prodded more retailers to open their doors on Thanksgiving, a day before the traditional start of the holiday season.
articles.lead_paragraph: Teenagers and college students can spend only so much time cooped up with their families on a holiday like Thanksgiving.

articles.headline: IBM to Announce More Powerful Watson via the Internet
articles.snippet: Companies, academics and individual software developers will be able to use Watson at a small fraction of the previous cost.
articles.abstract: Companies, academics and individual software developers will be able to use Watson at a small fraction of the previous cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Welcome to the age of supercomputing for everyone.

articles.headline: Ireland Is to Exit Its Bailout, and Without a Safety Net
articles.snippet: The country said that it opted against first seeking a precautionary credit line.
articles.abstract: The country said that it opted against first seeking a precautionary credit line.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ireland announced on Thursday that it would make a clean break from its international bailout program next month and do it without first seeking a precautionary credit line.

articles.headline: Obama Moves to Avert Cancellation of Insurance
articles.snippet: President Obama, bowing to pressure, said insurers could temporarily keep people on health plans that were to be canceled. But there is no guarantee that insurers will do so, or that the states will allow the renewals.
articles.abstract: President Obama, bowing to pressure, said insurers could temporarily keep people on health plans that were to be canceled. But there is no guarantee that insurers will do so, or that the states will allow the renewals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, trying to quell a growing furor over the rollout of his health care law, bowed to bipartisan pressure on Thursday and announced a policy reversal that would allow insurance companies to temporarily keep people on health plans that were to be canceled under the new law because they did not meet minimum standards.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Robert Pear
